report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: The open-source community is rapidly growing both in size and importance as individuals and organizations are increasingly reliant on OSS (open source software) to meet business needs within shorter time frames.

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: Widespread use of open source software has motivated malicious actors to take advantage of the medium, spawning significant and widespread attacks.

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: As this field of open source security develops, its likely a good idea to adopt some practices already instilled in other security fields.

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: One hunting technique that can be translated to the field of OSS security involves searching for reappearances of various Indications of Compromise (IOCs) in other places as a sign of malicious activity.

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: To be able to identify these threats at scale we automated this process and are using multiple data points to try and find relations between known malicious activity and yet-to-be-discovered ones using our hunting engine.

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: Checkmarxs Supply Chain Security team is continuously accumulating data from package managers and version control systems such as GitHub and GitLab, among other things, to discover correlations for known threats and uncover new related ones.

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: In order to find these relations, we track new packages released to numerous package managers and store, among other things, the following details:

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: Metadata package name, description, VCS repositories and users, owners names, and emails. Extracted IOCs URLs, IPs, cryptocurrency wallets etc.

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: This data allows us to create clusters based on the relations we find, which many times include relations across several package managers. One of the uses of this is our ability to reveal new suspicious packages through their association to a package that is a known malicious one. The following research illustrates this process perfectly.

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: During an analysis we performed of one of the more famous datasets of open-source malicious codethe Backstabbers Knife Collection, we came across a PyPI package called Junkeldat

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: The setup.py file of the malicious junkeldat package included the following snippet:

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: Putting it simply, this code returns the IP address of a given hostnamein this case, www[.]dl01[.]pwnz[.]org encoded to base64. This package, which had been flagged as malicious back in 2018, was removed from PyPI.

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: The junkeldat PyPI package leaves us with a few unique identifiers that can help us hunt for suspicious connected packages:

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: junkeldatthe package name itself www[.]dl01[.]pwnz[.]org hxxp://pypi.python[.]org/pypi/junkeldat/a URL for the packages files

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: These unique strings from one malicious package relates to 3 packages (active at the time of our research), two of them are in other package managers:

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: https://pypi.org/project/somsomsom/ https://rubygems.org/gems/junkeldat

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: We decided to dig deeper into all three of them.

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: Attackers publishing packages in multiple programming languages is a growing concerning trend. The junkeldat package group is only one example.

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: The lack of communication and information sharing inside the open source ecosystem enables these packages to go undetected for long periods of time, We think that a formal central repository of malicious packages containing samples from different programming languages is crucial to detect those attackers and we are working with various parties make this happen and keep the open source ecosystem safe and clean.

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
chapter_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks
text: Malicious packages in multiple programming languages that went undetected for years were revealed by the Checkmarx Supply Chain Security team using advanced threat hunting techniques.

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
chapter_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks
text: The fact that the packages stayed undetected for such a long period of time is due at least in part to the lack of information sharing in the ecosystem and to lack of communication between the package managers.

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
chapter_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks
text: All of the packages in this blog are related to the same attacker and to a malicious package known to the community for several years. Looking at this single package and applying advanced hunting techniques helps us demonstrate that the attacks are not language-specific -- a fact that amplifies the need for cross-industry communication and information sharing.

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: Starting with the somsomsom code package (still available on PyPI today), we found it resembles the junkeldat in structure but contains no malicious parts. However, it does have a clear connection to our starting point package: the home page field in the metadata, also directing to hxxp://pypi.python[.]org/pypi/junkeldat/

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: The second clear connection is to the ruby gem junkeldat, that was non-malicious by itself, and likewise contains the homepage of hxxp://pypi.python[.]org/pypi/junkeldat/

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: So far, we saw two packages, still available, with clear connections to the original malicious junkeldat package. But now, things start to get more interesting.

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: As it turns out, NPM has its own version of somsomsom. The package includes a dist directory, where we found two tarballs of two other packages.

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: somsomsom package tree

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: The first (inner) package, somsomsom-1.1.0/package/dist/Junkeldat-1.0.0.tgz, has the same functionality as the original Junkeldat package, e.g., a DNS query for www[.]dl01[.]pwnz[.]org, but the other inner package holds much more.

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: After extracting somsomsom-1.1.0/package/dist/aync-4.15.2.tgz,The package.json file in it includes the following scripts section:

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: This crambo/endotheliulia.js file, registered as a preinstall script, is a dropper that first executes a run method. This method also performs a DNS query for the domain 1bed1ef1[.]dl01[.]pwnz[.]org.

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: This practice allows the attacker flexibility with regards to where they store their payload. If an IP was hardcoded to the code, like we have seen in the UAParser.js attack, for example, the attacker would have committed to a specific server address. In this case, as long as they are in control of the domain name, they can move the payload around on different servers and change the DNS records accordingly, without breaking the attacks flow.

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: The IP result of this DNS query is then passed on to the function with the revealing name install_malwar which does the following:

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: 1. Downloads payload from hxxp://1bed1ef1[.]dl01[.]pwnz[.]org/titleboard

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: 2. Saves the payload as a tmp file/tmp/simplicitarian

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: 3. Changes its permissions to 777

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: 4. Executes the file

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: Aside from the malicious functionality, which depending on the dropped file can be practically anything, the attacker also used (what seems to be) a misleading tactic to make it harder for analysts to investigate the code, and as a result, waste their time. The rest of the files in the package are organized in a nested directory tree with nonsense file names.

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: aync directories tree

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: Each of these files contains one encoded string variable, again possibly to make analysts decode each of these to see what it holds. If not for the pointer to crambo/endotheliulia.js in the package.json file it would have blended right in.

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: NPM indicates that none of these two packages are currently available on its registry, however, aync used to be available on NPM according to libraries.io

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: The somsomsom package was available on NPM three years after the PyPI package junkeldat was submitted to the backstabbers knife collection and removed from the registry. NPM removed this nested package only recently based on our report to them.

report_title: Attackers Target Packages in Multiple Programming Languages in Recent Software Supply Chain Attacks. Intro
text: Correlation chart of the packages and related unique identifiers
